qas.question: What code did Windows 8 change to?
What term did Microsoft give to its exception privilige for web browsing?
What different options did the desktop version have?

answers.text: able to permanently run in the background, use multiple background processes, and use Windows API code

plausible_answers.text: Windows API code instead of WinRT

qas.question: What code did Windows 9 change to?

plausible_answers.text: Windows API code instead of WinRT

qas.question: What code didn't Windows 8 change to?
What term didn't Microsoft give to its exception privilige for web browsing?
What term did Microsoft give to its exception privilige for file browsing?

plausible_answers.text: able to permanently run in the background, use multiple background processes, and use Windows API code

qas.question: What different options didn't the desktop version have?

context: Exceptions to the restrictions faced by Windows Store apps are given to web browsers. The user's default browser can distribute a Metro-style web browser in same package as the desktop version, which has access to functionality unavailable to other apps, such as being <a2_0><b7_0>able to permanently run in the background, use multiple background processes, and use <b3_0><b4_0>Windows <a0_0>API code<b7_0/><a2_0/> instead of WinRT<b4_0/><b3_0/><a0_0/> (allowing for code to be re-used with the desktop version, while still taking advantage of features available to Windows Store apps, such as charms). Microsoft advertises this exception privilege "<a1_0><b5_0><b6_0>New experience enabled<b6_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/>" (formerly "Metro-style enabled").
